segments.key_quote: Oh what terrible sufferings and what terrible injustices you good souls suffer for being the sons of religions personified you did not deserve to remain alive under those tribulations yet you are protected by the Brahmaness God and religion
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam where Bhishma Deva laments the suffering of the Pandavas despite their righteousness and acknowledges their divine protection.
segments.transcript: In this session, we will be discussing from the 12th verse of the 9th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam: Aho Kashtam Aho Anyayam Yadyuyam Dharma Nandanaha Jivitum Na Arhatha Klistam Vipradharma Chutashrayaha. The meaning of this verse is Bhishma Deva is speaking. Bhishma Deva said, "Oh, what terrible sufferings and what terrible injustices you good souls suffer for being the sons of religions personified. You did not deserve to remain alive under those tribulations, yet you are protected by the Brahmanas, God, and religion."

segments.key_quote: Duryodhana took undue advantage knowing very well that Yudhishthira is very righteous he took undue advantage of that and that is how Yudhishthira was uh and the Pandavas were cheated and sent away to exile in the forest for 13 years
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on Yudhisthira's unwavering adherence to Dharma, which Duryodhana exploited to cheat the Pandavas and send them into exile.
segments.transcript: So Bhishma Deva is speaking to the Pandavas. He is very much in line, not just with your sup& t√∫ & phimbs factory, he is in line with our spiritual warp positions, very happy that the Pandavas have won the battle, and he's shedding tears of ecstasy seeing the Pandavas having won the battle of Kurukshetra and got back their lost kingdom. So he is now remarking, "What terrible sufferings and what terrible injustices you good souls suffer." The Pandavas are headed by Yudhishtira. Yudhishtira is the son of Dharma, Yama Dharma Raja, Yama Raj, the one who gives justice. He administers justice to all those souls at the end of their human beings, at the end of their life. If they have deviated from the religious principles, then according to the degree of violation, they are given suitable punishment by Yama Raj. So Yudhishtira, as a son of Yama Raj, he knows perfectly what is Dharma, and he was very, very strictly following all the religious principles. And that was how Dyuryodhana was able to cheat Yudhishtira and the Pandavas, even though sometimes Bhima would actually protest against Yudhishthira's being very, very righteous against Duryodhana's cheating. Then even when Duryodhana, there was a lot of people who cheating, Bhima would protest, but still Yudhishthira would not break any religious principle in order to avoid getting cheated by Duryodhana. Duryodhana took undue advantage, knowing very well that Yudhishthira is very righteous, he took undue advantage of that, and that is how Yudhishthira was, and the Pandavas were cheated and sent away to exile in the forest for 13 years.

segments.key_quote: Shakuni decided I am going to completely destroy this Kuru dynasty so in order to destroy the Kuru dynasty he plotted with this Duryodhana knowing very well that Duryodhana wants to cheat the Pandavas
segments.summary: The speaker details Duryodhana's sinister plan to keep the Pandavas in perpetual exile and Shakuni's motivation for destroying the Kuru dynasty due to his sister Gandhari's marriage to the blind king Dhritarashtra.
segments.transcript: And Duryodhana was ruling for 13 years, and he was making all plans that when they come back, his plan was never that they should come back. You know how cleverly Duryodhana had sent them away in exile. He had sent them away for 12 years they live in the forest, and the 13th year, the last year, one year they live incognito, they have to hide somewhere. And if Duryodhana and party discover where they are hiding, then another 13 years they will go for exile. Duryodhana's plan was that he will have his informers everywhere, and wherever the Pandavas go for hiding, he'll discover, he'll point out the Pandavas are hiding here, and then send them again in 13 years. So he thought, "As long as I'm alive, or as long as the Pandavas are alive, I'll be ruling, because wherever the Pandavas are, I'll discover where they are hiding and send them again and again 13, 13, 13, 13 years." This was the plan, that sinister plan this Duryodhana had made in consultation with his maternal uncle Shakuni. Shakuni was very much angry at the Kuru dynasty because his beautiful sister Gandhari, who was the most eligible princess before she was married, she was married to the blind king Vritrashtra. So he was very, very unhappy, "My sister did not get a suitable husband." That was what Shakuni, the brother of Gandhari, was thinking. So when he saw that he could not stop Gandhari getting married to Dhritarashtra, then the blind king, he decided, "I am going to marry Vritrashtra, completely destroy this Kuru dynasty," because Dhritarashtra was the head of the Kuru dynasty as the emperor of the world. Of course, he was a caretaker king, but still Shakuni decided, "I am going to completely destroy this Kuru dynasty." So in order to destroy the Kuru dynasty, he plotted with this Duryodhana, knowing very well that Duryodhana wants to cheat the Pandavas, and in that way the Pandavas will not be able to rule the Kuru dynasty, successors will not be able to rule the world properly. He wanted that the Pandavas should not rule the world by being cheated of their claim for the throne. So he and Duryodhana plotted to cheat the Pandavas in a gambling match.

segments.key_quote: Shakuni he was expert in this gambling so he he arranged in such a way that always Duryodhana will win and Yudhishthira will lose the match and that's how Yudhishthira lost everything and simply was sent away to the forest
segments.summary: The speaker explains how Shakuni used his gambling expertise to ensure Yudhishthira's defeat, leading to the Pandavas' exile, and reiterates Bhishma's lament about the injustice they faced.
segments.transcript: You see, this is, this is how Duryodhana was not very, very intelligent in that sense to have cheated the Pandavas, but Shakuni, he was expert in this gambling. So he, he arranged in such a way that always Duryodhana will win and Yudhishthira will lose the match, and that's how Yudhishthira lost everything and simply was sent away to the forest. So Bhishma Dev was remarking, "Oh, how terrible it is that you good souls, you don't deserve to actually suffer in this way, because you're upright, you're morally upright, you're following all the religious principles perfectly, still you have to suffer so much injustice."

segments.key_quote: They should have died so many instances for example they were sent to a a palace which is built with shellac combustible material but Vidura came to know about this and secretly informed Yudhishthira and Yudhishthira with the help of Vidura actually managed to escape
segments.summary: The speaker recounts the story of the shellac palace, Duryodhana's attempt to burn the Pandavas alive, and how Vidura's warning allowed them to escape through a secret tunnel.
segments.transcript: And he's further telling, "You did not deserve to remain alive under those tribulations." They should have died so many instances. For example, they were sent to a palace which is built with shellac, combustible material. But Vidura came to know about this and secretly informed Yudhishthira, and Yudhishthira with the help of Vidura actually managed to escape this plot by Duryodhana. Duryodhana and Pati, they were living with the Kauravas in the same palace, but Duryodhana once made this plan that, "Why the Pandavas should share the palace with us? Let us build them a beautiful palace, a very, very nice palace elsewhere, and then let them live separately. Why they should share, why we should share?" So he built another palace, beautiful palace, but he had arranged the palace into a mountain that it be built with combustible material, shellac. And when the Pandavas have gone and settled down there, suddenly one day he will arrange to set it on fire and they'll be burnt alive inside before they can escape, because immediately the fire will spread everywhere. So this was Duryodhana's plan. And because Yudhishthira came to know from Vidura before even moving to that new palace, Yudhishthira arranged to secretly dig a tunnel from underneath that new palace. And they escaped, Pandavas escaped before it could be set on fire. In fact, the Mahabharata says the Pandavas themselves set it on fire and escaped.

segments.key_quote: But still, because of Dhritarashtra's blind affection for his son, unworthy son Duryodhana, and Duryodhana's enviousness and jealousy towards the Pandavas, that this whole plot was carried out.
segments.summary: The speaker highlights Dhritarashtra's blind affection for Duryodhana and Duryodhana's envy as the driving forces behind the plot to kill the Pandavas, emphasizing the deception involved.
segments.transcript: Through the tunnel. So when it was completely set on fire, everybody thought the Pandavas are inside that palace and they have been burnt alive. So even Dhritarashtra and Duryodhana, they knew that the Pandavas were not safe. They knew that they were supposed to be cheated in this way. But still, because of Dhritarashtra's blind affection for his son, unworthy son Duryodhana, and Duryodhana's enviousness and jealousy towards the Pandavas, that this whole plot was carried out. And they thought that they had effectively gotten rid of the Pandavas. But actually the Pandavas had escaped. So he was not going to escape. He was not going to escape.

segments.key_quote: Morality is always on the side of the righteous persons who are God-conscious people. Those who are godless, they can never be morally upright. Never, never.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that the Pandavas were protected by Brahmanas, God (Krishna), and religion because of their righteousness, contrasting this with the lack of morality in godless individuals like Duryodhana.
segments.transcript: So he was not going to escape. But he was not going to escape. So he was not going to escape. So, here it is said, all these types of terrible injustices, they actually were able to avoid being killed because of the protection by the Brahmanas, God, and religion. Brahmanas, because Brahmanas always bless those who are righteous, those who are following religious principles. Brahmanas will never extend blessings to sinful people, to unrighteous people like Duryodhana. They can never get the blessings of Brahmanas. Similarly, God, Krishna. Krishna is always on the side of Dharma. In the end of the Bhagavad Gita, it is said, "Morality is always on the side of the righteous persons who are God-conscious people. Those who are godless, they can never be morally upright. Never, never." Sometimes they make a show of being morally upright, but that is just a show. It is cheating, actually. It is to... To fool innocent people that we are very morally upright. We are truthful. We are honest. We are hardworking. But actually, if somebody is godless, even if they make a show of being honest, it is no real value. It is no real value. So, like that, Bhagavad Gita teaches us that morality is always with the god-conscious people, not with godless people. Always with the divine-natured people, never with demoniac-natured persons. Never. They cannot be morally upright. Not possible. So the Pandavas were protected, as Bhishma Deva is telling, by Brahmanas, by God, Krishna, and by religion.

segments.key_quote: The religious principles itself, is a protection. Those who follow religious principles, that religion, those religion, religion itself protects them.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that following religious principles provides protection, with Yama, the administrator of Dharma, safeguarding those who adhere to them and punishing those who violate them, which explains why the Pandavas survived numerous attempts on their lives.
segments.transcript: The religious principles itself, is a protection. Those who follow religious principles, that religion, those religion, religion itself protects them. In the sense, the administrator of religious principles, Yama. Yama will always protect those who are following religious principles. He will punish those who are law-breakers, those who are irreligious, those who are going, violating religious principles. And this is the reason always, the Pandavas did not actually get killed, so many times, they were attempted to be killed.
